result.execSummary:
The defendant James G. Williams was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct Ordinance Violation. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. James G. Williams

records.addlTxt: Final Reminder Notice with request to pay in full or set up payment plan has been sent to the Defendant's address in the file as of this date. Failure to pay or set up payment plan--warrant may be issued.
Reminder Notice

While the State has provided the court with information indicating it has complied with victim consultation law, the Court lacks information as to whether the State has complied with other victim rights including notification and whether the victim wished to provide a statement regarding sentencing or disposition /s/ TBE 01/30/18

The Court requires more complete information. 
 The Stipulation and Order does not indicate whether the defendant has successfully completed the Deferred Prosecution Agreement entered into by the parties which proposes this type of outcome. 
 The State has not provided the court with sufficient information indicating it has complied with victim rights, notification, and consultation law, nor has it indicated whether the victim wished to provide a statement regarding sentencing or disposition.  The Court would note that the District Attorney's responsibility goes beyond 971.095(2), but also includes all of 971.095, 950.04 and Wisconsin's constitution.
The Stipulation does not include the full amount of costs, which would impress upon the public the seriousness of the offense.

No violent or abusive contact with J.W. even while he is in custody. 
Do not possess any firearms or other dangerous weapons.
If he makes bond, turn over to the Portage County Sheriff's Department, any firearms or other dangerous weapons he owns or has in his position.
If restraining order is filed and/or granted, comply with terms of the temporary restraining order or injunction.

9/10/2015: Bond amended from no contact with J.W. to no abusive contact with J.W. from September 11, 2015 through September 13, 2015 so that the defendant may attend his daughter's wedding.  All other bond conditions shall remain in effect and the original bond conditions shall be reinstated after September 13, 2015.

Defendant James G. Williams in court with attorney Eric Sheets. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

10:58 AM Court calls case.
Atty Knaapen states appearances.

Address of Defendant is verified.

There is a plea agreement.
Defendant will plead to Count 2. Count 1 will be dismissed and read in.

Victim is present.
Victim previously wrote a letter, was submitted last October.
Court sees the letter that was filed in the file.

Court will take a moment to re-review the letter.

Atty Sheets addresses the Court, apologizes for the late delay.  Atty Sheets concurs with agreement.

Defendant concurs.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST Count 2.

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney Sheets for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge.

Court takes a moment to re-review the complaint.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to WITHHOLD entry of Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 1: Dismissed Without Prejudice
Count 2: Disorderly Conduct as a Domestic

11:15 AM Victim addresses the Court. 

Atty Sheets addresses the Court, there is a $5,000 cash bond posted, requests balance to be returned to Defendant.
Program fees would be to Champion Seminars, but the State does not know the cost.

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Sheets makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

Disorderly Conduct would be a $50 fine plus costs.  

State will provide what the fine/costs of DC ordinance would be as well as what the cost of the program will be, in order to pay these from the bond before balance is returned. Atty Knaapen states this can be done within 7 days.

Court finds agreement fair and appropriate.

BY THE COURT:
Count 2:
Court approves the agreement and signs the agreement

Atty Knaapen addresses the Court regarding current bond.  

BY THE COURT:
Cash bond is amended to $5,000 signature bond with same conditions except with one.
Clerk is to retain the amount for the Champion Seminar and final amout of the ordinance citation, figures to be provided by the DA's office within 7 days. Remainder of the bond is to be returned to the poster of the bond. 

Parties discuss restraining order.  

BY THE COURT:
If there is a restraining order in effect, this action will not affect that order.
